I thought Silver Lake's willingness to do the deal also has to do with the fact that they were allocated funds that has a time component to it so if Silver Lake fails to do a deal in that time frame, they lose that opportunity so they aren't as picky as, say KKR or TPG who declined to participate. And I thought in general buyout funds' record on big techs have been spotty? I could be wrong, but I thought i read somewhere that these deals aren't slam dunks returns based on historical performance.

Message.Title: The Vote
Message.Msg: I have 6,600 shares and I vote no @ $13.65
Keep them coming.

I am starting to believe the deal will be defeated. My logic is this: Let’s say somebody gave you a choice - $1000 today or $1000 in 3 months. Which would you choose? Of course you would take the money today. Give or take a few cents, the stock is trading at its buy-out price. If you thought $13.65 was a fair price, you wouldn’t wait for any vote. You would cash out now. So people who are still in are people who don’t think $13.65 is a fair price. These people will vote no. The people who would have voted yes are already out.
M dell will walk away at that price. 12 or 13 bucks a share is as high as he will go. imho.

Message.Title: How long will it hold up....
Message.Msg: when this deal collapses because shareholders are so sure it is worth far more? When the deal is off the table? When there are no other offers? Are all these heroes saying Dell is worth low $20's going to pay YOU for your shares at that price? I believe the privatization should have never even been contemplated. I hope longs do very well over the long run. But I think it's amusing to see longs being so contemptuous of the $13.65 when it was at just $11 before the rumours were published. Hey, guess what? Southeastern thought it was worth $24 when it was at $9! Did that matter? Now suddenly everyone is an expert on Dell's "true worth". Only problem is folks, that unless someone is willing to pay you for your shares the price you think its worth, then you are SOL. I thought the deal should have been priced between $14.50 and $15. But that's a LOT more money to pony up from $13.65. Would $15 even satisfy enough shareholders at this point? $15 would require another $2.35 billion. Do the math. If Dell was really worth low $20's, then why wouldn't anyone else take a run at it? Makes no sense. Someone else would swoop in and pay $15 or $16 if it's such a steal - no? Well, we'll see. You never know. But I'd be surprised if there are any other bidders. And Michael Dell would be a fool to pony up more money in an attempt to appease the shareholders. Does he really think another 40 cents a share will make the difference? lol. The share price would just go immediately up, and then shareholders would demand more. This deal is a farce. Let Dell attempt its turnaround. If the global economy cooperates, and they are successful, shareholders will see their $20+. If not, they will look back at $13.65 as a gift. As it should be.

Message.Title: Exactly
Message.Msg: Michael Klausner, who teaches business law and corporate governance issues at Stanford Law School, said it is both tricky and unusual in Dell’s case, given the huge stake of founder and CEO Michael Dell, who is “putting in a lot of money, which means he thinks it’s a good deal.” DELL 13.81, +0.02, +0.11% 2015105 MAMJJASON13F Klausner added, however that “I suppose on the other side, they’re saying, ‘Wait a minute, he knows something we don’t know.” Elson also highlighted this point, saying, “Management is buying you out, and management thinks there’s value there and they’re appropriating the value.” “Ultimately, it’s a natural and unsolvable conflict,” he added. And this conflict may be headed to a proxy battle. Dell’s two largest institutional investors — Southeastern Asset Management and T. Rowe Price — have come out against the deal, as have some smaller shareholders. Southeastern Asset Management has hired proxy solicitation firm D.F. King & Co., and is pushing for a buyout price of $24.

Topic.Title: After deal falls through and Mr. Dell starts unloaded his shares

Message.Msg: No. Corporate officers of publicly traded companies cannot dump shares. They must file a request to do so and any sales are staggered so as not to influence the price. That's law, dude.

Topic.Title: [EXCLUSIVE] In Depth DELL Research Report [MUST SEE]

Message.Msg: Awesome news

I am the Acting Chairman for Investors Liberation Movement. I believe that many public-companies like DELL would probably do better if privately held. Such privatization would also free up equity-capital for new IPOs, etc. Therefore, I strongly support DELL going private. From a casual glance of the Company's fundamental-metrics shown on Yahoo! Finance Statistics, the offered price seems adequate or even generous. Those who want more should produce a higher bid rather than simply oppose the offer. More power to them in that case!
Michael Dell bought 10.4M shares at $14.37 ($150M) on 3/17/11. What does that tell you?
